entry.title: Mornings in an empty apartment
entry.summary: I have been struggling with loneliness for several years now. I do miss having a partner in life, but I don't want to get married either. Probably because I feel if I get married in this emotional state, it will just be a patch-work/a band-aid and I'll never be …
entry.content:
I have been struggling with loneliness for several years now. I do miss having a partner in life, but I don't want to get married either. Probably because I feel if I get married in this emotional state, it will just be a patch-work/a band-aid and I'll never be able to fix the root of my emotional problem. I have always been a little distant to people, a little awkward. But I was really happy at some point in life being single, and not missing a companionship.

I do feel I have moved on from her, but I never moved on the feeling of being defeated by love. That someone I cared about so much from the bottom of my heart will never love me the same way I loved them. It has always been hard to accept it. And this feeling of needing someone to feel happy about myself has stayed since then. Yes, it's a little immature of me considering I'm already 30 years old. I really want to be the guy who is happy by themselves and once I have reached that emotional state it will be the right time for me to marry.

The steps I took to avoid feeling lonely are sort of like a patch-work too. While I can't write about that here, people close to me already know about it. And that trauma doesn't help either. I feel I'm slowly getting distant to my college friends too, because I don't find anything common to discuss with them anymore. It doesn't help when they remind of the fact that I'm growing distant. It's so hard to even cry, it's like a part of me has gone numb after her. I feel choked with emotions but do not find an outlet to resolve those pent up emotions.

Writing about it here, helps a little, as I express a little bit of anger here. And I always said, this blog is not for regular audience, it's only for my own personal consumption. I need to get started to work, the last thing I want is to have my work impacted too because of this. This morning is not so good, but it's still a day and I should get started.

Coffee helped a bit

entry.title: external monitor setup with qtile, x11 on arch linux
entry.summary: I was thinking of how to use an external monitor in the vertical setup, although I was able to achieve the intented setup a little bit, I'm still not sure how I am going to use it Haha. But I also learnt a lot about Qtile api and how things …
entry.content:
I was thinking of how to use an external monitor in the vertical setup, although I was able to achieve the intented setup a little bit, I'm still not sure how I am going to use it Haha. But I also learnt a lot about Qtile api and how things work on X11.

So to achieve this setup, first I needed to use xrandr to achieve a vertical orientation of external monitor to the right of my laptop. To generate a script with the orientation I used arandr which is a GUI tool and can generate the xrandr script to initialize the external monitor.arandr generated the below script, and you can see how HDMI-1 is rotated right and the exact position of monitor 

1
2
#!/bin/sh
xrandr --output eDP-1 --primary --mode 2880x1800 --pos 0x0 --rotate normal --output HDMI-1 --mode 1920x1080 --pos 2927x0 --rotate right --output DP-1 --off --output DP-2 --off

Next step was configuring Qtile window manager, which was a little tricky. Basically I needed Qtile to do 3 things

  • Have 3 groups 7, 8, 9 on the new monitor, while group 1..6 should stay on laptop screen
  • Seamlessly able to switch groups without losing the focus on any screen. For eg - if I have a terminal opened on group 1 (laptop screen), and a browser opened on group 7 (external monitor), then switching to group 7, should not change the content of group1 in any way.

I had to hack and wander around a lot but I was able to achieve this with following configs 

groupbox1 = widget.GroupBox(visible_groups=['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '7', '8', '9'], highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25)
groupbox2 = widget.GroupBox(visible_groups=['7', '8', '9'], highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25)

@hook.subscribe.screens_reconfigured
async def _():
    if len(qtile.screens) > 1:
        groupbox1.visible_groups = ['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6']
    else:
        groupbox1.visible_groups = ['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '7', '8', '9']
    if hasattr(groupbox1, 'bar'):
        groupbox1.bar.draw()

This piece of code defines the groups and hooks I needed to use. The qtile hook screens_reconfigured gets invoked whenever there is a change in xrandr output.

Notice the multiple groupboxes, these are defined so that when if only laptop screen is active we show all the groups, otherwise we split groups between laptop and monitor.

The screen section of config get updated to something like this 

Screen(
    top=bar.Bar(
        [
            groupbox1,
            .....
            //rest of the widgets



),

Screen(
    top=bar.Bar(
        [
            groupbox2,
            #widget.GroupBox(highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25, visible_groups=['7', '8', '9']),
            widget.WindowName(fontsize=bar_font_size),
            widget.Clock(format="%a %I:%M %p", fontsize=bar_font_size)
        ],
        35,
        margin=[15, 20, 10, 20],
        #border_width=[2, 0, 2, 0],  # Draw top and bottom borders
        #background="#00000000",
        #border_width=[2, 0, 2, 0],  # Draw top and bottom borders
        #border_color=["ff00ff", "000000", "ff00ff", "000000"]  # Borders are magenta
    ),
    wallpaper="/home/ryuk/Downloads/dragon-ball-kid-goku-moon-halloween-wallpaper-scaled.jpg",
    wallpaper_mode="fill",
    # You can uncomment this variable if you see that on X11 floating resize/moving is laggy
    # By default we handle these events delayed to already improve performance, however your system might still be struggling
    # This variable is set to None (no cap) by default, but you can set it to 60 to indicate that you limit it to 60 events per second
    # x11_drag_polling_rate = 60,
),

Notice now we have 2 screens in config, and the second screen also takes a wallpaper parameter to automatically use a vertical monitor when it is connected and set the wallpaper.

The real magic of switching however happens with below keybindings I use for Qtile, they check for available screens and if the length of screens list is greater than 1, then switching works

def go_to_group(name: str):
    def _inner(qtile):
        if len(qtile.screens) == 1:
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
            return

        if name in '123':
            qtile.focus_screen(0)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
        else:
            qtile.focus_screen(1)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()

    return _inner

def go_to_group_and_move_window(name: str):
    def _inner(qtile):
        if len(qtile.screens) == 1:
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=True)
            return

        if name in "123":
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=False)
            qtile.focus_screen(0)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
        else:
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=False)
            qtile.focus_screen(1)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()

    return _inner

for i in groups:
    keys.extend(
        [
            # mod1 + group number = switch to group
            Key(
                [mod],
                i.name,
                lazy.function(go_to_group(i.name)),
                desc="Switch to group {}".format(i.name),
            ),
            # mod1 + shift + group number = switch to & move focused window to group
            Key(
                [mod, "shift"],
                i.name,
                lazy.function(go_to_group_and_move_window(i.name)),
                desc="Switch to & move focused window to group {}".format(i.name),
            )            # Or, use below if you prefer not to switch to that group.
            # # mod1 + shift + group number = move focused window to group
            # Key([mod, "shift"], i.name, lazy.window.togroup(i.name),
            #     desc="move focused window to group {}".format(i.name)),
        ]
    )

entry.title: How to copy from vim to global clipboard on linux
entry.summary: Having installed arch linux again, I am going back to vim style of editing the files. I use neovim specifically and recently I struggled with how to yank lines from your editor to a global clipboard. This is needed at times when you want to copy something from your editor …
entry.content:
Having installed arch linux again, I am going back to vim style of editing the files. I use neovim specifically and recently I struggled with how to yank lines from your editor to a global clipboard. This is needed at times when you want to copy something from your editor like code for eg to a clipboard and paste it in browser.

I didn't knew that anything which is yanked or deleted in vim is stored into a register. To see the current content of all the registers, run :reg in command mode.

How to copy

  • First you have to go into visual mode in vim using Shift + V then you can select the lines you want to copy, if it is the entire thing to end of file then you can also press G.

  • Once the lines are selected the next step is to yank them into a system clipboard register. In case of system clipboard in linux the register is +. So to copy into clipboard we simply do it using "+y to yank the selected lines in visual mode

I am really curious about the functionalities of registers in vim now. After all it's called one of the most powerful editors with a high learning curve due to a reason. Haha

entry.summary: I managed to solve 3 simple implementation problems today, all 3 related to string manipulation of some kind. I used the most brute force way to solve the problems, however I should check out the leetcode pattern for string problems. The thing is, I didn't want to go too quickly …
entry.content:
I managed to solve 3 simple implementation problems today, all 3 related to string manipulation of some kind. I used the most brute force way to solve the problems, however I should check out the leetcode pattern for string problems. The thing is, I didn't want to go too quickly into the solution pattern as I am learning the implementation and I'm sure such problems will be arriving soon.

Anyway here's the code for all the problems and the links to the problem, so that I can review the syntax used.

Problem1

func strStr(haystack string, needle string) int {

    for i := 0; i < len(haystack); i++ {
        if haystack[i] == needle[0] {
            if isSubstring(i, haystack, needle) == true {
                return i
            }
        }
    }

    return -1
}

func isSubstring(startIdx int, haystack string, needle string) bool {
    i := 0
    for startIdx < len(haystack) && i < len(needle) && haystack[startIdx] == needle[i] {
        i = i + 1
        startIdx = startIdx + 1
    }

    if i == len(needle) {
        return true
    }

    return false
}

Problem2

func isAnagram(s string, t string) bool {
    smap, tmap := make(map[byte]int), make(map[byte]int)

    for i:= 0; i < len(s); i++ {
        smap[s[i]]++
    }

    for i:= 0; i < len(t); i++ {
        tmap[t[i]]++
    }


    for key, val := range smap {
        if tmap[key] != val {
            return false
        }
    }

    for key, val := range tmap {
        if smap[key] != val {
            return false
        }
    }

    return true
}

Problem3

func repeatedSubstringPattern(s string) bool {
    for chainLength:= 1; chainLength <= len(s)/2; chainLength++ {
        if doesChainRepeat(chainLength, s) {
            fmt.Println("Found chain of length ", chainLength)
            return true
        }
    }

    return false
}

func doesChainRepeat(chainLength int, s string) bool {
    for startIdxOne:= chainLength; startIdxOne < len(s); startIdxOne = startIdxOne + chainLength {
        fmt.Printf("Chain Length: %d, startIdxOne: %d\n", chainLength, startIdxOne)
        i,j := 0, startIdxOne
        for ; i < chainLength && j < len(s); i,j = i+1, j+1 {
            if (s[i] != s[j]) {
                return false
            }
        }

        if (i != chainLength) {
            return false
        }
    }

    return true
}

entry.content:
I have started practicing the leetcode Programming Skills study plan. To grasp a language quickly, it has progressive set of exercises. I started with a problem where you were given two strings and you had to merge them alternatively, eg - word1 - "Hello" and word2 - "World" then the function should return a concatenated string "HWeolrllod".

Here is the code which I came up with 

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    const (
        word1 = "Hello"
        word2 = "World"
    )

    fmt.Println(mergeStringsAlternatively(word1, word2))
}

func mergeStringsAlternatively(word1 string, word2 string) string {

    word1Len := len(word1)
    word2Len := len(word2)

    var mergedString string
    i, j := 0, 0

    for ; i < word1Len && j < word2Len; i, j = i+1, j+1 {
        mergedString += string(word1[i])
        mergedString += string(word2[j])

    }

    for ; i < word1Len; i++ {
        mergedString += string(word1[i])
    }

    for ; j < word2Len; j++ {
        mergedString += string(word2[j])
    }

    return mergedString
}

While doing the problem I found out there are some really cool ways to use for in Golang. As I come from C like languages and Java background a while loop has been pretty much ingrained into my body. I do think Go has done a remarkable job capturing the essence of while loops with a for style loop.

Notice how the declaration can be done independently outside of for construct, and how both variables i,j can be incremented together. Definitely impressed with the construct. string on the other hand gave me pretty much a headache. I think the problem is that I started asking Gemini. rune, byte, slice of runes and a lot of things I tried resulted in failure. I'm sure this will get easier with time as I learn the internals, but for the time I will still keep my opinion that strings in golang are hell.

entry.title: Creating 2-D arrays in golang
entry.content:
I was doing leetcode problems because being prepared doesn't harm anyone, haha, and I'm also trying to learn golang in parallel. Going through the basic syntax currently and a lot of time scenarios arise where you have to initialise a 2-D array eg- graphs, or for dynamic programming problems. Here we use built-in make function to create a slice in golang. So this implementation is a slice of slices. I read there is other way of creating 2D arrays as well but I'll explore that later as this seems simpler to me. 

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    const columns = 5;
    const rows = 6;

    var multiDimensionalArray [][]int = make([][]int, rows);
    for i := 0; i < rows; i++ {
        multiDimensionalArray[i] = make([]int, columns);
    }

    // Accessing rows and columns
    for i := 0; i < rows; i++ {
        for j := 0; j < columns; j++ {
            multiDimensionalArray[i][j] = 1;
        }
    }

    fmt.Println(multiDimensionalArray);

}
